destination.label: Munich
destination.title: Munich: the cultural home of the German soul

content.intro:
Spot-lit by its artistic and cultural pluralism, the rich capital of Bavaria is the second tourist destination in Germany, just behind Berlin. Its unique heritage is the fruit of Catholicism, Romanticism, a prestigious dynasty the House of Wittelsbach and the vital force of nature.

Munich is more than a city; it is a vibration. It is the inner resonance of the German artistic soul, which rings from the domed bell towers of its Late Gothic cathedral (Frauenkirche). A vibration that no fire or bombing can destroy, it can be felt in the National Theatre of Bavaria (Bayerische Staatsoper), the Residence of the Wittelsbach House (Munich Residenz), and in the ‘art district' (Kunstareal). These cultural phoenixes are constantly being reborn, their grandeur magnified by that of their content and architecture.

Nourished on Schweinshaxe (pork knuckle with grated horseradish and potatoes) washed down with beer from its breweries and its Biergartens, Munich is resolutely festive, and not just during Oktoberfest. It is also creative, and focused on the future. It is a city in motion, once damned, like Faust, and then entirely rebuilt. You will get gloriously swept up by its romantic fervour, just as Ludwig II, the King of Bavaria, was by the operas of Wagner, the scenes of which he had recreated as frescoes on the walls of his glorious Neuschwanstein Castle (‘Schloss Neuschwanstein'). And that celebratory fervour will overwhelm you during your visit to the mecca of European football, the Allianz Arena, home of Bayern Munich, and then again, when you visit the BMW Museum. In Munich, everything is a matter of style and design, and all is alluring, especially at the city's famously comfortable hotels, where the legendary Bavarian service, from the bed to the plate, is exceptionally warm and attentive. A perpetual feeling of understated luxury attaches itself to every step you take in Munich, and, of course, it comes with a price. The capital of Bavaria has never been cheap.

The feelings the city generates, however, are priceless, and much of them come from surrounding nature. Travellers will see it everywhere in Bavaria, from Chiemsee to Konigssee, Starnberg to Ammersee, Bodensee to Forggensee and Tegernsee, and in the many lakes that dot the countryside. We apprehend as much from these enchanting, idyllic landscapes as we do from the artistic camps born here, which encompass both traditional and avant-garde movements. Their lines and brushstrokes are as pure as the nearby peaks of the Austrian Tyrol, and help illustrate how Munich was, and remains, a formidable artistic, cultural, and scientific centre, never ceasing to expand its vocabulary of correspondences between colours, sounds, and words.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Munich

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Munich  - Plan your trip to Munich with Air France Travel Guide

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Munich

content.title: Wirtshaus Maximilian, modern food in a traditional Bavarian inn

introduction.small: Near the Isar River in Munich, Wirtshaus Maximilian offers Bavarian gastronomy with a modern twist in a folkloric setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wirtshaus Maximilian, modern food in a traditional Bavarian inn

paragraphs.text:
With an old-school, almost tacky red and white sign, Wirsthaus Maximilian looks exactly like a typical Bavarian tavern. The inn – Wirsthaus in German – reveals a quaint atmosphere, between the huge fireplace that welcomes visitors, the local beers, inviting and comforting food as well as all staff dressed in period clothing. Folklore is being perpetuated yet modernised: you will not find any hunting trophies on the walls, but a much more contemporary design, with a black wooden counter and a stripped-down decoration. The menu follows on that trend, offering traditional recipes with a twist. The Bavarian style is greatly influenced by Austrian gastronomy, and especially the Tyrol region. Indulge in schnitzels from Munich made from veal fillets, and served with potatoes, lettuce and cranberries, or the Alpensau, which is pork belly in cream and beer. This is proof that tradition and modernity can go hand in hand!

Wirtshaus Maximilian
Westermühlstraße 32
80469 Munich

+49 89 7404 0854

www.wirtshaus-maximilian.de  ﻿

Menu: around 28 EUR

content.title: Play the adventurer in the Partnach Gorge

introduction.small: Less than two hours from Munich, discover the Partnach Gorge during a trek between waterfalls and river basins.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Play the adventurer in the Partnach Gorge

paragraphs.text:
In the Bavarian Alps, near the Garmisch-Partenkirchen Olympic site, you will put on your trekking shoes to explore the narrow Partnach Gorge. Listed as a natural monument since 1912, it runs over 700 metres and zigzags between natural waterfalls. The trail takes about two hours and remains easily accessible, no matter what shape you are in.
Walk between steep cliffs and their tumultuous rapids, and explore the geological formations shaped by the Partnach River. A perfect experience to be one with nature, it can be performed in all seasons, as much under summertime bright lights as winter frozen environment, which shapes the waterfalls into gorgeous sculptures. You cannot leave before crossing the 70-metre high suspended iron bridge, from which to enjoy spectacular vistas that are worthy of the trip in themselves.

Partnach Gorge (Partnachklamm)
Wildenauer Straße

82467 Garmisch-Partenkirchen

www.gapa.de/en/Ort-Umgebung_en/Attractions/Partnach-Gorge ﻿

content.title: Sport, culture and music at Olympiapark München

introduction.small: Relive the passion of the 1972 Munich Olympics by visiting its famous park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sport, culture and music at Olympiapark München

paragraphs.text:
In the Bavarian capital, tourists flock around a monumental structure that was built to host the Summer Olympic Games in 1972. In more than forty years, the Munich Olympic Park has continued to grow to become one of the most important recreation centres in the world. In addition to the sports events promoted here, it is also the scene of many cultural and commercial events: concerts, fairs, screenings, conferences and exhibitions.

From the panoramic TV tower, you can see the stretched canvases that connect the different spaces of the park. Soccer, hockey, skating, fitness, running, tennis, mini-golf, boating, rollerblading—the activities offered in the indoor and outdoor areas are varied and, when the winter is cooling down in the region, you will love to cruise down Olympic hill on the kids' sled!

Olympiapark München
Spiridon-Louis-Ring 21
80809 München

+49 89 306 72 707

www.olympiapark.de/olympiapark-muenchen

content.title: View of the city from the top of Saint Peter's Church

introduction.small: The oldest church in Munich offers a breath-taking view of the city from the top of its belfry.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: View of the city from the top of Saint Peter's Church

paragraphs.text:
In the historic district of Munich stands the bell tower of St. Peter's Church. The locals prefer to call it Alter Peter or ‘Old Peter', since it is the oldest church in the city. Built between the 11th and 12th centuries on Petersberg hill, it has suffered with the throes of history and has had to be rebuilt many times. You thus visit a Gothic sanctuary with a Baroque heart. The central bell tower was rebuilt in 1386, in the place of two original towers that had collapsed.

Inside, you can see the relics of St. Munditia, a Christian martyr, whose skeleton is covered with gold and precious jewels. To reach the top of the belfry, you will have to climb 300 steps, but once you reach the top, you will not regret it. The observatory offers a panoramic view of all of Munich, especially the old town and the Frauenkirche. If the weather is clear, you can even see the peaks of the Alps.

Peterskirche
Rindermarkt 1
80331 München

+49 89 21 02 37 760

www.erzbistum-muenchen.de

content.title: The Munich Residenz: Antiquarium shrine

introduction.small: The palace of the residence of the Wittelsbach House has 130 rooms in different styles, filled with masterpieces and jewels. Among them is the sumptuous Renaissance Antiquarium gallery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Munich Residenz: Antiquarium shrine

paragraphs.text:
The Munich Residenz is one of the most important museums in Bavaria. This jewel, open to the public since 1920, was once the home of the Wittelsbachs, one of the oldest royal families in the Holy Roman Empire, rulers of Bavaria and the Palatinate, the territory of the German Empire ruled by the Count Palatine of the Rhine.

The palace residence was built and enlarged over several centuries, and thus contains a variety of architectural styles : Gothic basements, Renaissance halls, gardens and wing, Baroque gallery and bedrooms, Rococo apartments, treasury and theatre, an imposing facade, and a classical chapel. Visit the Hall of Ancestors and ceremonial rooms, the porcelain and silverware rooms, and the reliquary.

Then go to the sumptuous Antiquarium, which Alain Resnais shot to bewitching effect in Last Year at Marienbad. The 69-metre-long barrel vault the longest Renaissance hall north of the Alps—has 17 recessed windows, between which run the gorgeous frescoes and antique busts.

Munich Residenz
Residenzstraße 1,
80333 München

+49 (0)89 290 67 1

www.residenz-muenchen.de

content.title: Munich under the heavenly chimes of the Frauenkirche

introduction.small: In the kingdom of Rococo cathedrals, the Late Gothic Frauenkirche towers above the rest. The largest church in Munich is also a striking emblem of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Munich under the heavenly chimes of the Frauenkirche

paragraphs.text:
Five minutes from the lively Marienplatz stands Munich's very bare and austere cathedral. The impressive carillon from the two medieval bell towers, which both contain ten bells, impose their sacred harmony over the city.

The Frauenkirche (Church of Our Lady) was built in red brick in 1468. Its two Late Gothic towers dominate the city. Lacking money, the city chose to cover them with Renaissance domes, instead of open-worked spires, 37 years after their construction, and modeled them on the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem.

The view from the top of the south tower is breath-taking. At the entrance to the nave, one can put one's shoe in the Teufelstritt, (Devil's Footprint), a black mark said to have been made by the devil himself when he stood at the door and ridiculed the ‘windowless' church.

Frauenkirche
Frauenplatz 12,
80331 München

+49 (0)89 290 08 20

www.muenchner-dom.de

content.title: The Louis Hotel: a great location with beautiful bohemian decor

introduction.small: A chic and cosy haven near the major monuments of Munich, with delicious Japanese fusion cuisine and many rooms with terrace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Louis Hotel: a great location with beautiful bohemian decor

paragraphs.text:
The Louis Hotel is a chic boutique hotel with a bohemian air. The stone fireplace and wood furnishings in the entrance are very welcoming, while the 72 guest rooms, with their warm colours and simple decor, reflect the same spirit.

Their white-dominated palette marries nicely with the ochre carpets and oak parquet floors, the fine oak and hazel furniture, and the metro-tiled bathrooms. Choose one of the many rooms with a terrace for a picturesque view of the streets of Munich. The restaurant, Emiko, serves delicious Japanese fusion cuisine, served on plates to share and composed of fresh products from the city's famous market, the Viktualienmarkt, located next door.

When the sun comes out, sit on the terrace where multi-coloured parasols invite you to laze over a flute of Champagne and a plate of sushi.

Louis Hotel
Viktualienmarkt 6,
80331 München

+49 (0)89 411 19 080

www.louis-hotel.com

Rooms: from 160 EUR

content.title: Mediterranean cuisine at the Gandl Feinkost Speisen Bar

introduction.small: Pleasant service, tasty food, and a friendly ambiance characterise this neighbourhood spot, which combines classic French and Italian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mediterranean cuisine at the Gandl Feinkost Speisen Bar

paragraphs.text:
An Italian restaurant and delicatessen, located in an old grocery selling colonial products, the Gandl is a neighbourhood local that never empties.

You can stop there to read your morning newspaper while drinking a delicious coffee accompanied by an excellent pastry. At noon, you can enjoy home cooking with Mediterranean accents before checking out the bottles of balsamic vinegar, olive oils, and pasta packets on the shelves of this charming place, where the service is always friendly. Watch the incessant ballet of passers-by on the square or sit quietly in a rattan chair in a room decorated with photographs.

On the menu: herb-crusted monkfish, gazpacho, and hearty spaghetti Bolognese, with a nice selection of wines by the glass to accompany things. The brunch buffet, served on Saturday morning, is very popular.

Gandl Feinkost Speisen Bar
St.-Anna-Platz 1,
80538 München

+49 (0)89 291 62 525

www.gandl.de

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: Zum Goldenen Kalb: calling all carnivores !

introduction.small: Meat lovers will be in their element in this Munich institution, a great spot that is far too trendy to be cheap.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zum Goldenen Kalb: calling all carnivores !

paragraphs.text:
True to its name, Zum Goldenen Kalb (The Golden Calf) is a paradise for meat lovers. Generous home-cooked dishes are served here, first and foremost being the excellent steaks, served with fries or potato gratin.

Charts depicting various beef cuts adorn the walls to help you identify your favourite portion of cow. The chequered tablecloths on wooden tables make for a warm and welcoming atmosphere, enriched by Galicia tapas and gazpacho.

Groups of six or more can serve themselves directly from the refrigerated cabinets, where expensive longhorn sirloin steaks and wagyu rib-eyes await. The wines, alas, are pricey, too, and served by the glass. Vegetarians however, are not left out; vegetable dishes are also available.

Zum Goldenen Kalb
Utzschneiderstraße 1,
80469 München

+49 (0)89 235 42 290

www.zum-goldenen-kalb.de

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: The Charles Hotel: a university library, now a spacious hotel

introduction.small: A place of cosy accommodation near the Old Botanical Garden, with spacious rooms and the city's longest in-door pool.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Charles Hotel: a university library, now a spacious hotel

paragraphs.text:
The Charles Hotel, part of the Rocco Forte Hotel group, instils a dose of modernity and cosmopolitanism in the landscape of luxury hotels in Munich. Its location is a major advantage, since many of the hotel's rooms have views of the Old Botanical Garden.

Renowned for its warmth and attention, its 136 rooms and suites are all at least 42 square metres making them the biggest in Munich and are very bright and airy, with thick carpets in a palette of natural colours, well thought-out lighting, and luxurious bathrooms. The Davvero restaurant has an elegant terrace and serves excellent Italian cuisine, and the piano bar mixes very good cocktails.

To recover from your active day, enjoy a relaxing session in the spa, or a swim in the pool, which is beautifully decorated with coral mosaics.

The Charles Hotel
Sophienstraße 28,
80333 München,

+49 (0)89 544 55 50

www.roccofortehotels.com/

Rooms: from 306 EUR

content.title: Wagner's score at Neuschwanstein Castle

introduction.small: At 90 minutes from Munich by car is the magnificent ‘Schloss Neuschwanstein', which contains, in every room, a fresco based on a Wagner score. Utterly fascinating.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wagner's score at Neuschwanstein Castle

paragraphs.text:
The high towers of the castle are silhouetted atop a rocky wooded spur with a beautiful snow-capped mountain background. Built in the 19th century, this symbol of Romanticism was commissioned by Ludwig II of Bavaria, and designed by the chief architect of the kingdom, Eduard Riedel.

A flamboyant mix of Neo-Gothic and Late Romanesque style, it is visited annually by more than a million people, who come mainly to see the dazzling Neo-Byzantine throne hall and the rooms, each of which is richly decorated with frescoes and paintings depicting scenes from the operas of Richard Wagner.

Tristan and Isolde are in the king's chamber, Siegfried is in the entrance hall, Tannhauser is in the workroom, and, of course, Lohengrin is with his swan. If at all possible, avoid visiting this magical place during the summer, when more than 6,000 tourists flock to it daily.

Schloss Neuschwanstein
Neuschwansteinstraße 20,
87645 Schwangau

+49 (0)83 629 30 830

www.neuschwanstein.de

content.title: Hofbraukeller: on the banks of the Isar, a beer lover's paradise

introduction.small: This hundred-year-old spot on the Isar River in the Haidhausen district is a family place with very reasonable prices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hofbraukeller: on the banks of the Isar, a beer lover's paradise

paragraphs.text:
Hofbraukeller is open from 10:00 a.m. to midnight, giving you ample time to sample the many Bavarian beers on tap. In the friendly, relaxed neighbourhood of Haidhausen on the banks of the Isar, the Hofbraukeller attracts people in summer to its beer garden, which is shaded by the majestic chestnut trees on the Wiener Platz. It is a festive atmosphere, and has been for more than one hundred years. A range of Bavarian specialties are served, at very honest prices, like deer stew with pear and cranberries, or cep mushroom fritters with pesto. When winter sets in, the Neo-Renaissance building welcomes you in a rustic room with vaulted ceilings, while on the lower floor at night, the Café Maratonga becomes a dance floor. A babysitting service is also available.

Hofbräukeller am Wiener Platz
Innere Wiener Straße 19,
81667 München

+49 (0)89 459 92 50

www.hofbraeukeller.de

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Surf's up in the English Garden

introduction.small: The city's large public English Garden, (Englischer Garten) in the northeast of Munich, offers many activities, including surfing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Surf's up in the English Garden

paragraphs.text:
Created in the 18th century in the district of Schwabing in northeast Munich, this magnificent area of 368 hectares is one of the largest urban parks in the world, and a sanctuary for riders, picnickers, walkers, and cyclists.

Visit the artificial island in the popular southern section of the park, attend a traditional tea ceremony in the Japanese tea house, or have a pint of Bavarian lager in one of four beer gardens. You can also visit the Chinese pagoda, 25 metres high, and discover the traditional cuisine of Seehaus.

Or go surfing! Despite the sign Baden verboten, surfers train every season in the artificial watercourse the Eisbach (river of ice) fed by the glacial Isar river, which comes down from the Alps and causes a constant wave of about one metre high. The best spot to catch it is on the Himmelreich Bridge.

+49 89 386 66 390

www.muenchen.de

content.title: Tantris: sacred shrine of German gastronomy

introduction.small: The legendary Tantris restaurant, one of Germany's best, is famous for its inspired cuisine, attentive service, and very cool 1970s decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tantris: sacred shrine of German gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
Tantris is one of the best restaurants in Germany, and has been since 1971. In 1991, star chef Hans Haas took over the kitchens of this legendary place, succeeding internationally renowned chefs like Eckart Witzigmann and Heinz Winkler. Haas prepares inventive and inspired food: roasted lobster with Jerusalem artichoke mashed; venison medallions with red cabbage; and rack of lamb au gratin with beans. Try his delicious and very sophisticated tasting menus—five to eight dishes—to discover the full range of his talents. With its vintage 1970s red decor by Swiss architect Justus Dahinden, Tantris continues to attract hip followers—as much for the truly amazing service as for the fantastic food and incredible wine list.

Tantris
Johann-Fichte-Straße 7,
80805 München

+49 (0)89 361 95 90

www.tantris.de

Menu: around 130 EUR

content.title: Munchen Palace: a boutique hotel of a special kind

introduction.small: Experience the time less elegance of this boutique hotel in Bogenhausen. Cosy and chic, it's ideally situated for museum goers and lovers of theatre and good food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Munchen Palace: a boutique hotel of a special kind

paragraphs.text:
The elegant Munchen Palace is endowed with an innate elegance and the charm of luxury without a shred of ostentation. Popular among musicians and actors on tour, this chic and cosy hotel rivals the greatest palaces of the Bavarian capital. Its 73 rooms and ten suites are decorated in a palette of soothing tones. The bathrooms are impeccable, and each is equipped with an island-style bathtub. Located in the quiet residential area of Bogenhausen, just steps from Prinzregenten Theatre, several museums, and the English Garden, its shaded courtyard and fourth-floor terrace are delightfully peaceful. Stop in at the hotel bar, especially in winter: the wood panelling and fireplace will warm you up before you head to the excellent restaurant. In fine weather, you can dine outside on the very romantic garden terrace.

München Palace
Trogerstraße 21,
81675 München

+49 89 41 97 10

www.muenchenpalace.de

Rooms: from 225 EUR

content.title: The fishing's always good at the Brenner Grill

introduction.small: An elegant grill restaurant, close to Munich's main shopping streets, with a nice fish and pasta menu at reasonable prices. For meat, the prices go up.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The fishing's always good at the Brenner Grill

paragraphs.text:
An elegant wine bar and a superb grill are waiting for you under the majestic arches of the Brenner, in the former stables of the Munich Residenz. This is a great favourite of demanding meat lovers ready to pay the price. Guests can dine outside on the lovely terrace lined with potted olive trees, or in the vaulted hall, supported by rows of Doric columns. The centre of the restaurant is occupied by the charcoal grill, where gilthead bream, rib steak and swordfish filets with mango are cooked to perfection. The Brenner Grill's pasta dishes are delicious: Sicilian tagliatelle with swordfish, capers and olives; spaghetti calamaretti… Rest assured that you will eat well, in a spacious and elegant setting, and at a reasonable price (as long as you don't order the super-expensive Black Angus steak).

Brenner Grill
Maximilianstraße 15,
80539 München

+49 (0)89 452 28 80

www.brennergrill.de

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: The Neue Pinakothek: a showcase for 19th-century art

introduction.small: The Neue Pinakothek shows 19th-century art in all its forms: German (and European) Romanticism, Historicism, Realism, Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, and Symbolism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Neue Pinakothek: a showcase for 19th-century art

paragraphs.text:
The Neue Pinakothek is another cultural phoenix in Munich. Founded in 1853 by Ludwig I of Bavaria to house his personal collection, it was destroyed by bombing in 1944, and reopened in 1981.

Designed by the great German church architect Alexander von Branca, it houses an impressive number of masterpieces, many of them acquired by its first director, Hugo von Tschudi, who collected Géricault, Delacroix, Courbet, Manet, Degas, Monet, Seurat, Signac, Renoir, Cézanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh, and Toulouse-Lautrec.

Symbolism is well represented here, as is the Jugendstil movement. Paintings by Denis, Ensor, Holder, Vuillard, Munch, and Schiele also help assuage the feelings of sadness caused by the temporary closing of the Alte Pinakothek…

Neue Pinakothek
Barer Str. 29,
80799 München

+49 (0)89 238 05 195

www.pinakothek.de

content.title: Tradition reigns supreme for the 16 days of Oktoberfest

introduction.small: Oktoberfest is one of the world's greatest festivals, attracting millions of people every year.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tradition reigns supreme for the 16 days of Oktoberfest

paragraphs.text:
The first Saturday of the second half of September starts the world's biggest funfair: the Oktoberfest, Munich's annual beer festival. This giant bash is held in Theresienwiese, an open space in the Munich borough of Ludwigsvorstadt-Isarvorstadt.

The beer is sold in liter mugs in 14 giant tents, as well as more modest enclosures and smaller Biergartens (beer gardens), accompanied by Bavarian orchestras, fairground attractions, and food stalls. The world's biggest popular festival, it was established on October 17, 1810, following the marriage of the future King Ludwig I of Bavaria to Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen.

Every year, as locals and tourists hoist their steins, tradition comes alive under the Ferris wheels, in a cheerful, noisy, and authentic atmosphere. Prost !

Oktoberfest
Theresienwiese
80336 München

www.muenchen.de

content.title: Mandarin Oriental: a five-star hotel in the Old Town

introduction.small: One of Munich's most luxurious hotels mingles German comfort with oriental style. In 2015, its embrace of exoticism moved into the kitchen, now run by star Peruvian-Japanese chef Nobu Matsuhisa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mandarin Oriental: a five-star hotel in the Old Town

paragraphs.text:
An elegant 19th-century building, just a few minutes from the Marienplatz, the Mandarin Oriental Munich, the city's luxury benchmark, is a popular hotel for all types of royalty.

Behind its majestic white facade, an imposing staircase leads you to great views of the city and a gorgeous swimming pool. The 73 rooms and suites offer up a discreet sense of luxury, evident in the furniture, the ochre tones, and the hotel's rich collection of paintings. The restaurant, Matsuhisa, opened in November 2015 by Peruvian-Japanese star chef Nobu Matsuhisa, is similar to his Matsuhisa in Beverly Hills.

In summer, enjoy a cocktail on the roof at the China Moon, where, on a clear day, you can see the Alps in the distance. In winter, enjoy the cosy Bavarian-chalet comfort of the Mandarin, with mulled wine and traditional music.

Mandarin Oriental Munich
Neuturmstraße 1,
80331 München

+49 (0)89 290 98 0

www.mandarinoriental.com

Rooms: from 575 EUR

content.title: Anna Hotel: stunning decor and creative lighting

introduction.small: Close to the busy shopping area around Kaufingerstrasse, Anna Hotel has a strong personality and a dynamic approach to interior design.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Anna Hotel: stunning decor and creative lighting

paragraphs.text:
Anna Hotel is the work of New York decoration brand Donghia, known for its skill in mixing traditional and modern styles. Just off the busy shopping street Kaufingerstrasse, the hotel is loaded with surprises, like showers with lights that change from red to purple, and some spectacular pieces of contemporary sculpture.

The 75 hotel rooms (52 ‘design' rooms), spread over six floors, are furnished with flowing lines and noble materials: the floors are teak, and the black granite bathrooms are all equipped with sunken bathtubs. Book the Tower Room for great views of the Frauenkirche Cathedral.

In the bar, the glossy parquet reflects the multi-coloured lights, while, in the restaurant, neon pink animates the room's elegant grey palette. The food is excellent: seasonal German with an Asian touch.

Anna Hotel
Schützenstraße 1,
80335 München

+49 (0)89 599 94 0

www.annahotel.de

Rooms: from 120 EUR

content.title: The Allianz Arena is a chameleon

introduction.small: Residence of the legendary Bayern Munich football club, the Allianz Arena is an architectural wonder.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Allianz Arena is a chameleon

paragraphs.text:
A shrine of European football, the Allianz Arena has changed its name twice in its short history because of stadium advertising restrictions. It was known as the ‘FIFA World Cup Stadium Munich' during the 2006 World Cup and is still called the ‘Fußball Arena München' for UEFA competitions.

Germans know of it fondly as the Schlauchboot (dinghy). The property of Bayern Munich, it is also the home park for TSV 1860 Munich. The 75,000-seat arena was designed by Herzog & de Meuron and opened in late April 2005.

Its facade is made of sheets of self-cleaning air cushions, which are lit from within and let the sunlight through, which keeps the grass happy. Thus, just as it changes its names, the stadium can change colour depending on the type of competition: white for international matches, red for Bayern, blue for TSV Munich…

Allianz Arena
Werner-Heisenberg-Allee 25,
80939 München

+49 (0)89 699 31 222

www.allianz-arena.de

content.title: The Pinakothek Museum of Modern Art

introduction.small: In 2002 Munich built a new cathedral, in glass this time, devoted to 20th century art: the Pinakothek der Moderne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pinakothek Museum of Modern Art

paragraphs.text:
The Pinakothek der Moderne is nicknamed the ‘Cathedral of Glass' because of its rotunda and saw-tooth glass roof. Built in 2002 by the Munich architect Stephan Braunfels, its 12,000 square metres house four museums: Modern Art; Decorative Arts and Design; Graphic Arts; and Architecture.

Its masterpieces of classical modernism include those by Beckmann, Kandinsky, Klee, Picasso, and Margritte. And those of the next generation, represented by Bacon, Baselitz, Beuys, Judd, de Koonig, Polke, Twombly, and Warhol are here, too.

There is also an impressive collection of works by Die Brucke (The Bridge), a group of expressionist artists founded in Dresden, and by Der Blaue Reiter (The Blue Rider), a group formed in Munich in 1911 by Wassily Kandinsky and others.

Pinakothek der Moderne
Barer Str. 40,
80333 München

+49 (0)89 238 05 360

www.pinakothek.de

content.title: The BMW Museum: on the highway of architecture

introduction.small: The universe of this famous Munich-based brand is elegantly reflected in the architecture of this stunning museum. Inside? Five thousand square metres of design and technological wonder.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The BMW Museum: on the highway of architecture

paragraphs.text:
BMW obviously likes Austrian architects. Facing the sumptuous and gigantic BMW Welt showroom, by Wolf Dieter Prix (2007), is the headquarters of the Munich auto manufacturer and its museum, entirely redesigned in 2008 by the brilliant Viennese professor Karl Schwanzer.

Known as the ‘salad bowl' or ‘white cauldron', it contains BMW-designed engines, turbines, aircraft, motorcycles, and, of course, cars, plus a plethora of futuristic-looking models and conceptual studies.

One of the most visited museums in Munich, it also showcases the brand's racing history and its collaborations with artists, including Alexander Calder, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, and, most recently, Jeff Koons.

BMW Museum
Am Olympiapark 2,
80809 München

+49 (0)89 125 01 6001

www.bmw-welt.com

content.title: The Bavarian State Opera: the phoenix of opera houses

introduction.small: Constantly destroyed and rebuilt, the Bavarian State Opera, Richard Wagner's cradle of creation, focuses as much on a German repertoire as on world premieres.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bavarian State Opera: the phoenix of opera houses

paragraphs.text:
First built in the old city at Salvator Platz Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart premiered Idomeneo there in 1781 the Bavarian State Opera moved in the early 19th century into the Munich Residenz.

A neoclassical building, commissioned by King Maximilian I of Bavaria and designed by Karl von Fischer, it was destroyed by fire in 1823 and again reduced to dust during the Second World War. Yet this first jewel of the works of Richard Wagner, thanks to Ludwig II, the King of Bavaria, never ceases to be reborn from its ashes.

Succeeding Kent Nagano, the music director since 2013 has been the great Russian conductor and pianist Kirill Petrenko. The opera company focuses mainly on German operas and ballet but also presents numerous world premieres.

Bayerische Staatsoper
Max-Joseph-Platz 2,
80539 München

+49 (0)89 218 50 1

www.bayerische.staatsoper.de

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Munich
content.introduction: Munich straddles two climate regions: humid Atlantic and dry continental. For this reason, the weather can be quite changeable and unpredictable. Winters are cold, with some snow due to the proximity of the Alps, whereas summers are relatively hot and humid. Thunderstorms occur frequently in the summer. Spring is the ideal time to visit the city, with its clear and sunny blue skies.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Germany is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Munich Franz-Josef-Strauß International Airport
airports.description:
Munich's Franz-Josef-Strauß Airport is located about 28 kilometres (17 miles) north-east of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Munich and back
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A99 ring road, the A9 and the A92. The trip to or from central Munich takes about 45 minutes.
    • The airport offers several parking facilities opposite or adjacent to the terminals for long-term parking (P41, P80 and P81) including free bus transfers to the terminals (between EUR 2 and EUR 5 depending on the facility).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in hall C of Terminal 1.
  • By bus
    • MVV Bus has routes connecting the airport with Freising, Erding and Markt Schwaben.
    • Lufthansa Express Bus connects the airport with Munich's main train station every 15 minutes.
  • By rail
    • Two S-bahn commuter rail lines (S1 and S8) connect the airport with central Munich every 10 minutes.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks just outside the arrivals halls. The trip to central Munich costs around EUR 70.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +49 (0)89 97500
  • Website: https://www.munich-airport.com/passengers-visitors-75328

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Munich
transportation.description: Munich has an efficient public transport system covering all areas of the city. It is by far the best option for getting around.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Munich, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: München Tourismus
information.description:
Offers practical information and many useful recommendations (accommodation, public transport, sightseeing and tours) as well as brochures and maps.

  • Address: Sendlinger Str. 1, 80331 München
  • Opening hours: Monday to Thursday from 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. and Friday from 9:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.
  • Telephone: +49 (0)89 233 96 500
  • Website: https://www.muenchen.de/int/en.html

information.title: Tourist information centres
information.description:
At various locations throughout the city, München Tourismus operates information centres, where you can obtain recommendations for visiting Munich and its surrounding area:

Main train station (Hauptbahnhof):

  • Address: Bahnhofsplatz 2, 80335 München
  • Opening hours: 9 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. Monday to Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday and holidays

City hall (Rathaus) :

  • Address: Marienplatz 8, 80331 München
  • Opening hours: 9:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Monday to Saturday, and 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday and holidays

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Munich counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic German phrases that will make your stay in Munich a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Guten Morgen (morning) / Guten Tag (during the day)
Could you repeat ?: Können Sie bitte wiederholen?
What time is it ?: Wie spät ist es?
How much is (…)?: Wie viel kostet es?
Where can I find (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) finden?
Where can I buy (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) kaufen?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Munich
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Munich each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 1: New Year's Day (Neujahrstag - national holiday)
From Epiphany to Shrove Tuesday: Munich carnival (Fasching -local event)
events.description: Carnival season in Munich begins on the day after Epiphany and ends on Shrove Tuesday. Munich thus pulls out the stops for a month or more each year, celebrating this period with a series of costume parades as well as fancy dress parties and elegant masked balls.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (Tag der Arbeit -  national holiday)
Late June–late July: Munich Opera Festival (Münchner Opernfestspiele - local event)
events.description: An annual highlight since 1875, this festival organized by the Bavarian State Opera attracts visitors from around the world for its top-flight productions, featuring today's leading artists in over 30 opera performances, along with song recitals, symphonic and chamber music concerts, and dance performances, at various venues throughout the city.

events.title: Mid-September–first Sunday in October: Oktoberfest (local event)
events.description: This is Munich's legendary folk festival, featuring huge and smaller tents for enjoying a variety of beers and gourmet specialities, with traditional music and dancing, and a fun fair with wild rides, games and food stalls. It takes place on the Theresienwiese, a gravelly open space near the centre of the city, and attracts some 6 million visitors each year!

events.title: October 3: German Unity Day (Tag der Deutschen Einheit - national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the anniversary of Germany's reunification in 1990.

events.title: November 27–December 24: Christmas Market (Christkindlmarkt - local event)
events.description: Munich's Christmas market is consistently one of the most impressive in Europe. It is held every year on the beautiful Marienplatz.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Germany
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Germany for less than three months. For stays longer than three months, you will need to apply for a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) from the Immigration Office (Ausländeramt). You will need to provide proof of sufficient financial resources to fund your proposed stay and proof of accommodation in Germany (Wohnungsbescheinigung). You will also need to be in possession of a valid national identity card or passport.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Munich and Germany, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Germany page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: view information for travellers to Germany

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Thursday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Friday from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

banks.title: Banks

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Germany, as is also the case in France and Italy, when the service is especially friendly and attentive, leaving a tip is recommended and always appreciated. An appropriate tip in this case is anywhere between 5 and 10% of the bill at restaurants or bars. Do not leave the tip on the table. It is better to hand it to the server when paying the bill.
